draft.title: New draft
draft.unlocked: Unlocked document is public. Locked document is password-protected. Both are protected. You can always unlock any document. See examples
draft.btn_title_protect:
It is currently on Testnet, which means that the certification of authorship does not formally comply with copyright law.

If you wish to create a copyright certificate that formally complies with copyright law, go to the Mainnet. To do so, you will need to register and select the tariff that applies to you.

Also on the Mainnet you can check your content and submit pre-trial claims in case your content is used by third parties.
draft.btn_title_save_close: Save and close and work on it later

locked_content.title: This content is password-protected
locked_content.content: The author decided to hide the content of the document and protected it as locked. You can check whether it was later republished unlocked by checking its<|>versions<|>. If so, you’ll see a password to access this file there. Then, you can download it by clicking on the IPFS QR-code.

certificate.quote_content: If you want to quote this content, add a link to the original publication or<|>a link to this certificate<|>, please.

faq.title: Common questions
questions: What is a certificate?<|>A certificate is a document that contains all data which verifies authorship, based on the principle of a surplus of evidence.

How do I use the certificate?<|>If you are the author, then the certificate serves as proof of your authorship. If a violation is detected, SharpShark will use this certificate to resolve the dispute in a dialogue with the violator. You can also use it in other cases yourself, where you need to prove your authorship.
Why do I need QR codes?<|>QR codes are needed to quickly view records in the IPFS and blockchain.

How long is the certificate valid for? How long will my text be protected (for)?<|>Once a certificate has been issued, it is protected indefinitely. You will always be the owner of your certificate and be the author of the content, even if you unsubscribe from SharpShark. All content becomes a part of the public domain 70 years after the author’s death (depending on the country).
Can I delete my data/content?<|>The content itself cannot be deleted, but your personal data can be. Imagine that your content was published, as if you had published a book.

Is it possible to give up authorship?<|>The right to be called author is inalienable, and the waiving of such rights usually makes them null and void. This means that no one else can be named as the author of your content. You can transfer the rights to use your content, meaning that you are still the author but the content is commercially used by the copyright holder. You can be a ghostwriter on behalf of a third party, but this is not within Shark’s purview.

But, you can try to voluntarily refuse, so that the work becomes a part of the public domain, if your country’s law/legislation allows it. Though, officially, everyone will still know who the author is.

If you are unable to do so, the deal will still be void. The best way around this situation is to publish the content under a pseudonym.
